Award.AwardTitle: Tapping the Untapped Rural Areas to Improve Engineering and Physics Higher Education in Eastern Iowa and Western Illinois

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This project is focused on increasing enrollment and graduation rates in industrial engineering, mechanical engineering and physics. The expectation is to serve more than 15 students yearly through the articulation of a seamless transfer from the community clleges. It is particularly noteworthy that the program builds on proven 'in house' methods that have yielded excellent retention results and that it continues to focus on underserved populations. Enhancements to be included are adopting and enhancing a STEM Summer Research Program and a Student Success Center, hiring tutors and research assistants, faculty mentors to help with retention, utilizing good connections with industry, and integrating two good recruitment tools (Girl's Night Out and The Robotic Hand).

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
With assistance from this S-STEM grant, St. Ambrose University increased enrollment and graduation rates in industrial engineering and mechanical engineering by (1) teaching rural high school students about engineering and physics careers and creating more seamless matriculation pathways from rural community colleges to recruit more students; (2) selecting qualified students to receive scholarships; (3) developing an applied research program and augmenting current academic success initiatives to support students academically; (4) continuing to partner with industry to facilitate our graduates’ career placement or graduate school attendance; and (5) developing the department and faculty by creating opportunities for advancement through undergraduate research. These strategies targeted students from rural communities who are underrepresented in STEM fields with a goal of increasing enrollment by at least 75 students more than the 2011 baseline over five years.

 

No two years of grant activities were exactly the same. We learned from our experiences each year and worked to improve upon what was working and change what was not. We started off

Traveling to high schools and middle schools in a short amount of time to conduct an hour-long workshop with students. This turned into a much more reasonable, yet equally effective, schedule that included fairs around the region that would reach more students. A new event was created just for girls that continues to grow and flourish, serving well over a thousand girls in 5 years. We hope, will make a significant impact on the number of women in engineering in the years to come. Exploring Engineering events morphed from presentations about engineering disciplines into Career Exploration Fairs where area industry partners attended to talk to middle school, high school, and college students about what engineers do at their companies.

 

A template transfer advising plan was created in collaboration with a local community college that was used to develop further plans with other regional community colleges. An advising program was also created with regional community colleges. The number of transfer students into our programs increased dramatically (from 4 to 28 annually), as did our overall enrollment (from 62 to 130 total).

 

A variety of support strategies were developed to improve retention. A new Engineering Ambassador program was created that is very effective at both recruitment and retention of students. Scholarships were provided to a total of 46 high-need, highly qualified students.

Modified by: Jodi F Prosise
